commands.name: chmod
commands.summary: CHange MODe - change the permission of the file/directory.

examples.description: Add the Read permission for the User who owned this file doc1.txt.
Add the Write permission for the User who owned this file doc1.txt.
Add the eXecute permission for the User who owned this file a.out.
Add the Read and eXecute permission for the User who owned this file a.out.
Remove the Read permission for the User who owned this file a.out.
Remove the Read, Write and eXecute permission for the User who owned this file a.out.
Add the Read permission for the file owner's Group.
Add the Read permission for Outsiders, aka the public. It means everybody who doesn't belong to file owner's group can read the file.
Add the eXecute permission for the User who owned this file and the user's Group.
Add the Read, Write and eXecute permission to everyone.
Remove the Write permission for the file owner's Group and Outsiders.
Add the eXecute permission for all files with the suffix .sh to the User who owned this file.

Set the permission of the file to "rw-r--r--". Note that it uses octal numeric system to represent permission. "644" is an octal number. Deciphering it into binary we get "110 100 100". 1 means to turn the permission on and 0 is off. For the first field "110", the leftmost 1 means to toggle the read permission on; the middle 1 means to toggle the write permission on; the last 0 means to turn off the execute permission. This process is similar for "100" and "100". Therefore, we get "rw-r--r--" at last.
Set the permission of the file to "--- r-- ---". That means only the file owner's group except the file owner can see the content of the file.

tips: For your information, permission of any file/directory can be viewed via `ls -l`.

u: user, owner of the file/directory.
g: file/directory owner's group.
o: outsiders/public who don't belong to the owner's group.

r: read permission which determines whether the person can view the file.
w: write permission which determines whether the person can write the file.
x: execute permission which determines whether this file can be treated as an executable and run.
